Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Thermal Rectification and Heat Transfer Enhancement via Near-Field Radiation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1509691
Sangi Reddy, Pramod

This research is to understand how energy flows between two surfaces placed very close together, with gaps as small as 10 nano-meters. The resultant data are significant because knowledge gained will help establish methods of manipulating energy flow effectively in small devices. There have been many models predicting these behaviors, but relatively few experimental results exist to verify or disprove them. This proposed study will facilitate model validations. The proposal also incorporates extensive outreach activities to engage undergraduate and graduate students as well as underrepresented minorities in research. Modules for K-12 students will incorporate novel atomic force microscope, which is impressive.

This project aims to validate and invalidate the developed theories and numerical studies on the near field radiation between nano-gap parallel plates. The PIs have successfully demonstrated preliminary measurements of the 200 nm gap radiation and plan to reduce the gap down to 10 nm. The experimental setup will be used to validate many combinations of materials and radiation rectifier and enhance the performance of calorimeter (with pico-Watt resolutions). The experimental facility is being developed on a current NSF award. Several significant questions regarding near-field radiation heat transfer in nano-gaps will be addressed: (1) near field heat transfer polar dielectrics and hyperbolic materials, (2) thermal rectification, and (3) high resolution calorimetry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Any hot body emits energy in the form of electromagnetic waves. Understanding thermal radiation is of great importance for numerous applications in engineering and science in general. From a fundamental viewpoint, the study of thermal radiation played a central role in the development of Quantum Mechanics. Max Planck successfully laid down the principles of far­field radiative heat transfer at the beginning of the 20th century. However, Planck explicitly noted that his theory was only applicable to situations where the separation between the objects involved in the radiative heat transfer is significantly larger than the wavelength of radiation with dominant contributions to radiative heat transfer (~10 μm at room temperature). With the advent of micro­ and nano­technology, the need to understand thermal radiation in nanoscale gaps has become extremely important. While some progress has been made in understanding radiative heat transfer using spherical geometries, the canonical and technologically relevant plane­-plane geometry has remained experimentally inaccessible.In the work perfromed in this project, we overcome this challenging hurdle by developing novel experimental tools that enable the study of radiative heat transfer between parallel planes between both dielectric and metallic surfaces for the first time. More importantly, using these tools we demonstrated that it is possible to attain heat currents between bodies that are orders of magnitude larger than the blackbody limit! Further, we showed how it is possible to use near-field thermal radiation to both create thermal diodes and novel energy conversion devices (near-field thermophotovoltaic devices) that can convert heat to electricity with much higher power outputs than what was possible with state-of-the-art thermophotovoltaic devices.
